ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE TECHNOLOGY COMPANIES


    1. Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence, to maximise the productivity of our limited pool of manpower, whether he will consider directing companies belonging to the Ministry of Defence to concentrate on security-related or very high-tech businesses instead of manufacturing and selling personal computers.

     Mr Speaker: Question No. 1, Mr Philip Tan.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, before asking the Question, I would like to declare that I am in the computer software business though I am not in the business of manufacturing personal computers for sale. Secondly, I also want to declare that I am a council member of the Enterprise Development Council. This Council was formed by the Economic Development Board to promote and develop local enterprises to play a bigger role in Singapore's economic growth in the 1990s.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The principal purpose of setting up the Singapore Technology (ST) companies is to provide technical and industrial support to the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF), to enhance its operational effectiveness and strengthen our economic defence.

    However, ST cannot do this solely by undertaking work for the SAF. No defence group in the world does this unless self-sufficiency is to be achieved at all costs. Strengths and capabilities which the SAF will need only in a contingency will almost by definition be surplus to requirements in peacetime. The same technology used by the SAF can often also be employed for civilian purposes. For example, both military data terminals and civilian personal computers require similar integrated circuits and printed circuit boards.

Column: 270

To develop a capability for one and not to use it for the other would be wasteful.

    MINDEF's policy is therefore that ST companies should, besides SAF work, also undertake industrial and commercial activities which have synergies with, support or extend the core defence-related activities. This may mean "crowding out" the private sector from the business. But from the point of view of the nation as a whole, it is better for the defence industries to do this and channel the private sector into other areas of business, rather than for the defence industries to keep their surplus capacity idle in order to give the business to the private sector.

    ST companies are required to maintain a clear business focus. They only undertake those non-military activities which make sense for the core mission of their companies, where there is synergy with the defence business. They are not allowed to practise predatory pricing, or take advantage of their Government-owned status to hide costs and win contracts. They must compete for business on equal terms with private sector companies.

    Electronics and computer systems are pervasive and important components of modern weapon systems. While we cannot become totally self-sufficient in these areas, the ST companies can develop a comprehensive capability in these systems, to give the SAF the extra technological edge. This is why ST companies manufacture and sell personal computers.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, is the Minister aware that ST companies are also agents for personal computers?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, indeed. The SAF Enterprises (SAFE) retails many brands of PCs as well as other consumer goods as part of its business. In addition, SCS, which is an information technology systems house, provides PCs and other work stations as part of its total system solutions. That means, when it sells a consumer a package, it is selling a solution - hardware, software, integration, training support. Therefore, SCS has a standing business relationship with PC vendors, which reduces the cost of such total systems offered to the clients. It is

Column: 271

better for the clients. It gives them a more attractive package. Once SCS is a value-added supplier of PCs, there is no reason for SCS to turn down, customers who walk in and want to buy PCs off the shelf.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, is the Minister aware that the advertisements by the ST companies were on selling PCs as stand-alone hardware only?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know what advertisement the Member is referring to. I presume it was the advertisement for the Lynk computer which was designed, manufactured and sold by Chartered Electronics Industries (CEI).

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: I am referring to the ST company which is the agent for the AST personal computers.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, rather than argue what advertisements have been published or not, I take the position that even if they were published entirely as the Member has maintained, I see nothing wrong with it. Why should a commercial company, making a commercial decision, seeing a business opportunity, not go in to offer a service which their customers value and find useful?

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the point is actually we want to maximise the limited manpower pool that we have. The PC area is not a very high-tech area.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Tan, ask your question, please.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, I would like the Minister to consider whether this is in line with maximising the productivity of our limited manpower.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the line between what the Government should do, what the Government-owned companies should do, and what privately-owned companies should do, is a matter of degree, judgment and choice. From MTI's point of view, it makes absolutely no difference when a company sells a computer, whether the shareholder happens to be the Minister for Finance on behalf of the Government, or happens to be a private entrepreneur on his own behalf; provided he is operating on a level playing field,

Column: 272

provided that there is no hidden subsidy from the Government, provided that the Government is not favouring its own company and, therefore, enabling it to compete unfairly with the private sector. If the Government company can give the private sector a run for its money, so be it.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, I am wondering whether the Minister will comment on the statistics provided in the directory of the Singapore Federation of Computer Industry that there were five Government-owned companies employing 1,135 computer professionals as against 50 private companies with 4,802 employees. This works out to an average of 227 computer professionals per Government-owned company and 96 computer professionals per privately-owned company. Is it not true that the manpower has been drained away into the Government-owned companies?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, if tomorrow the Government decides to sell off one of its companies with 220 people to a private sector entrepreneur for $10 million or what ever it is worth, the averages are even out overnight. Does it make one jot of difference to the economy? Which is better for us? That whoever owns the company and whoever has the enterprise gets the individuals and puts them to productive use, or that the Government and its companies, when these have talent and ideas, stand by idle and do nothing in order that others who are less competitive can come in and monopolise the market at the expense of consumers? Surely it is better for resources to be used optimally and consumers to be better served. They are not forced to go to Government companies. They can, if they wish.

    Telecom - the next question - is not compelled to buy computers from the Government. In fact, we encourage them to tender or to explore R&D contracts with whoever is available. If the Government company is the best one, so be it. If the Government company were not there, are we so confident that there would automatically be a private company in its mould and image in its place magically? I doubt it.

Column: 273



     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, I beg to differ. Is the Minister assuming that the productivity of the Government-owned companies in the area of personal computers is higher than the privately-owned companies?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: I make no assumption, Mr Speaker, Sir. But these are Government-owned companies competing on fair basis, receiving no subsidies, hiring workers and yielding returns, and they are not losing money. So why should they not continue?

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, but how can we say that they are on a fair footing? The Minister should consider that there are certain factors that the Government-owned companies will have to take into account, for instance, land cost, rentals and even the attractiveness of employing people from the industry.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, Government companies pay for their land cost, they pay for their office rentals and, if there is any preference, I can tell you that people prefer to work in private companies rather than Government ones.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: I rest my case.

Column: 273

TELECOMMUNICATION AUTHORITY OF SINGAPORE
(Sourcing of personal computers)


    2. Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong asked the Minister for Communications and Information, in line with the Government's intention that the private sector be the engine of growth, why is the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore sourcing personal computers from Chartered Electronics Industries Pte Ltd, a Government-owned company, instead of from local private manufacturers.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, Telecom is not sourcing personal computers, as assumed in the Member's Question. The Member is probably referring to Teleview terminals which will be used very shortly when the Teleview system is available publicly.

Column: 274



    Sir, to keep costs down and to make the Teleview system as widely available as possible, and as soon as possible, Telecom has, instead of doing inhouse R & D and manufacturing its own terminals, decided to work together with other companies that have such capabilities. After assessing the R&D and manufacturing capabilities of a number of possible partners, Telecom has proceeded with two projects.

    The first is the research and development into a dedicated Teleview terminal to be used specifically for Teleview purposes. Telecom has been working with Marconi Command and Control System Ltd of the United Kingdom on this project for some years.

    More recently, Telecom is also developing together with Chartered Electronics Industries Pte Ltd a special Teleview terminal, an intelligent terminal, as it is called, with the ability to serve also as a personal computer. It will be a Teleview-cum-PC terminal. Such dual purpose terminals can help keep the cost of the terminal down and to make it attractive for large numbers of people to get on to the Teleview system.

    Telecom and the Chartered Electronics Industries Pte Ltd are also developing together other special accessories, including hardware cards and specialised software. These can be used to adapt any IBM AT or compatible personal computer to access Teleview.

    Sir, the Teleview system is the most advanced photo-videotext presently available. Terminals to access Teleview are not available off the shelf either in Singapore or in any other country. Hence, the need for joint development with the different companies.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, is a tender called for choosing of partners in the research? Does the partnership in development also include the manufacturing of PCs? Are local companies being approached for such a venture?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, as far as research and development is concerned, it is not possible to go out with a tender and ask for

Column: 275

participants. Therefore no such tender has been made. The engineers in Telecom are familiar with the capabilities of the different companies in Singapore, so, what Telecom has done is to approach a number of companies which may have similar capabilities with talent that may fit Telecom's R & D requirements. Telecom has looked at a number of these companies, and on the basis of the most attractive offer and the best fit with the objective of getting the Teleview system available as soon as possible, Telecom has settled on Chartered Electronics Industries.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, when the development has completed, will Telecom consider tendering out the PCs rather than following up with CEI in the manufacture of PCs?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, part of the contract for the R&D, which involves quite obviously capital investment on the part of the company itself, is for the manufacture of the terminal that will be developed. I want to emphasise to the Member that it is not a PC that is being developed. It is an intelligent Teleview terminal. Because the components have such a large overlap with that of a conventional PC, modifications have been made to the terminal so that it can function as a PC.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, is it not then that what Telecom is doing is not in line with the Government's intention that the private sector be the engine of growth?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I do not understand the Member's question. As far as I see it, and as my colleague, the Second Minister for Defence (Services) has mentioned a moment ago, a Government-owned company is as much a part of the private sector and the engine of growth. Just because the ownership is in the hands of the Finance Minister does not make that contributive of company any less important. If the company were to be sold tomorrow, it does not make one bit of a difference to the economy of Singapore. What is important is that they are able to be competitive. If Telecom had found another partner in Singapore, Telecom would have been just as happy working with that other company, developing the

Column: 276

intelligent terminal. And then as part of the contract, to tie up with the manufacture of that particular terminal.

    Sir, we have been working together with a British company for a long time producing the Mark I terminal. The Member has not been unhappy with that all this time. We are now developing with Marconi the Mark II terminal. The Member has not been uncomfortable with that at all. So I do not understand why the Member should be uncomfortable now that we are developing a terminal with a local company, Chartered Electronics Industries.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, is the Minister saying that a Government-owned company is no different from privately-owned companies and that a privately-owned company stands on the same equal footing as a Government-owned company? Secondly, I agree with the Minister that I have no quarrels with Marconi, because we do not have the technology. But here the question is: can Marconi not work with a locally-owned company which manufactures PCs instead of the Government?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the Member is obviously not aware of what is going on. It is not the technology of Marconi that we are interested. It is the expertise. We had done this job ourselves. Telecom has completed the development of the Teleview system. The system is likely to be much better than systems available elsewhere in the world. We could have done it all by ourselves if we so wish. But it would probably take us a few more years, by which time it may be superseded by new technology. So when you are working in a high-tech industry, you have to move quickly. And rather than go out and recruit a very large number of research engineers into Telecom to funnel them into this particular project so that we can bring the project to fruition as quickly as possible, Telecom does what is most natural, which is to scout around to see where talent in this field is. We found it in CEI. That is how the project has progressed the way it did. So we are able to launch the Teleview system soon. There will be three ways of accessing the Teleview system.

Column: 277



    Firstly, through the Marconi-built Teleview dedicated terminal. In other words, that terminal can only access Teleview and nothing else. Secondly, we are working together with CEI to come out with an intelligent Teleview terminal which will modify the previous terminal to give it the capabilities of a Personal Computer. Thirdly, for members of the public who have already got a PC, what Telecom and CEI are doing is to develop new hardware and software which can adapt the owner's own PC to access Teleview.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: Sir, is the Minister saying that Telecom has actually scouted around Singapore and found that the expertise in CEI is not found in any local company?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the expertise in CEI gives Telecom the best fit and it gives Telecom the greatest confidence that the project can be handled within cost and within schedule.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong: My question is whether Telecom has actually gone round to see the local companies and found that the expertise was not there and that was why Telecom had to resort to CEI?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, we have looked at a number of companies. It is not proper to name the companies that Telecom has looked at and has decided not to go into partnership with.

Column: 277

HDB RENTAL/PURCHASED FLATS
(Income ceilings)


    3. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether the income ceilings set for the application for Housing and Development Board rental or purchased flats will be reviewed.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the income ceiling for purchase of HDB flats was reviewed recently in 1989. Since 11th August 1989, the income ceiling for flats purchased directly from HDB has been raised from $4,000 to $5,000 per month for a nuclear

Column: 278

family and from $6,500 to $8,000 per month for an extended family. Based on the Labour Force Survey, 90% of the households in Singapore would qualify to purchase HDB flats directly from the Board with the latest revised income ceilings. HDB has also lifted the income ceiling for purchase of HUDC and resale HDB flats in the open market. There is no need to revise the income ceilings for purchase of HDB flats in the immediate future.

    Sir, the income ceiling for rental flats to Singapore citizens is currently set at $800 per month and a subsidised rental is charged. Rental flats are for citizens in the lower income groups who cannot afford to purchase home ownership flats. Households with incomes of more than $800 per month should be able to afford the monthly instalment payment for a 3-room flat in the New Town zone, and are encouraged to purchase their own flats. HDB, however, does exercise flexibility to allow Singapore citizen families with household incomes that slightly exceed the $800 ceiling to also rent flats. These cases are considered on their individual merits.

Column: 278

HDB RENTAL FLATS
(Transfer of tenancy)


    4. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether he will relax the rules on transfer of tenancy of Housing and Development Board rental flats to other sitting tenants.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the existing policy, tenancy of a rental flat can be transferred to the original permitted occupiers or "sitting tenants" under the following three situations:

    (a) Death of the registered tenant.

    (b) Separation or divorce from the registered tenant.

    (c) Registered tenant moving out due to other reasons.

    In cases of demise or separation or divorce from the registered tenant, HDB has recently relaxed its rules to allow the remaining single occupier to retain the

Column: 279

rental flat, provided he or she meets the normal conditions, such as citizenship. The condition of a family nucleus will be waived.

    Where the registered tenant has moved out for other reasons, the original permitted occupiers are only allowed to retain the flat if they can comply with all eligibility conditions for rental flats, such as family nucleus and income ceiling.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): Sir, is the Minister of State aware that there are permitted occupiers who have given undertakings that with subsequent changes they are not able to take up the flats? I would like to ask whether these occupiers would be allowed to take over the tenancy of flats which are supposed to be rented out?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid I have not got the point of the question. If they have given an undertaking that they do not wish to take up the flat, then that is the end of the matter.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, what I would like to clarify is that there are people who are allowed to occupy the flat but the HDB has in fact said that because they are not the permitted occupiers they would be allowed to stay in the flat when the original registered tenants leave the flat. There are quite a lot of them who are required to give up their flats. I would like to ask whether these cases would be reviewed sympathetically?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, I believe the Member is referring to those whom HDB has allowed to live in rental flats as a casual boarder. In this case, we cannot really treat a casual boarder on a better level than we treat those permitted occupiers. If the casual boarder needs rental housing, I think he should apply on his own and qualify accordingly.

Column: 279

HAJ PILGRIMAGE


    5. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for the Environment and Minister-in-Charge of Muslim Affairs whether he will make a statement concerning 242 Singaporean Muslims who recently nearly missed their Haj pilgrimage although all of them had paid fully for their trips.

Column: 280



    The Minister for the Environment and the Minister-in-Charge of Muslim Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, every year, before the start of the haj season, MUIS appoints pilgrim brokers after carefully screening their credentials. Pilgrim brokers help intending pilgrims to register with MUIS for the haj, provide training on haj rituals and look after their welfare in Saudi Arabia.

    MUIS also selects General Sales Agents (GSAs) who provide haj packages at competitive prices. The haj packages include board, lodging and internal travel in Saudi Arabia. Only those GSAs who are able to satisfy the conditions imposed by MUIS are selected.

    For this year's haj, MUIS selected 13 pilgrim brokers and seven GSAs. When their appointments were announced, MUIS advised intending pilgrims to deal only with these authorized pilgrim brokers and GSAs.

    The pilgrims referred to by Mr Chiam were those who went against MUIS' advice and paid money to a travel agent who was not selected by MUIS as a GSA.
